WaniKani_Meaning_Mnemonic: The kanji and the radical are the same, so remembering the meaning of this kanji is as simple as making sure you know the radical for enter first! If you know the radical, you know this kanji means enter as well.
WaniKani_Meaning_Info: Make sure you know those radicals, yo!
WaniKani_Reading_Mnemonic: Turns out, after you Enter the teepee (you'll remember that the radical is a teepee with a big entrance to it), you're given a new (ã«ã‚…ã†) car!
WaniKani_Reading_Info: Imagine lights turning on and flashing, and an entire audience inside. You're at a gameshow, and the announcer announces the neeeeew car in his announcey voice. Feel the surprise. Feel the happiness. Feel the excitement. Check the year on the car, too. It's this year! It really is new!

origin_of_ch_char_book: (å®‰, an, peaceful) is composed of a house (å…¥, ru, enter), and a woman sitting on her knees (å¥³, nÃ¼, woman). The woman is sitting comfortably at home. It seems that the house and wife were the symbols of stability for men. Someone came to such a peaceful house. (å®¢, ke=kâ€™e, visitor) describes a personâ€™s foot upside down . in front of the door . The character shows the lady of the house inside her home, and a visitor to the house.,(å…¥, ru, enter) is the shape of an ancient house. People back then dug a hollow in the ground and lived there or built a tree house to escape from the attacks of wild animals. shows a house made of reeds or tall grass on the ground, and it evolves to signify â€œenterâ€ or â€œincomeâ€.
humanum_full_description_en:
" Enter " is basically an indicator, like a pointed object, to point out the direction of "entering". "Shuowen": "Entering, inside also. Like from the top to the bottom. All those who enter are from the entry." " In " and "å…­" are the same characters, that is, the two characters have different meanings but the same writing , See " Six ". The glyphs of the ancient characters for " entering " are generally symmetrical, which is different from the character "äºº", which has different lengths on the left and right. The characters of the Warring States Period may be decorated with dots on the vertical painting of the character "å…¥", as shown in the 208-character bamboo slips of the tomb of Zenghou Yi. In the process of the Libian change, because the left and right strokes of the character "äºº" became symmetrical, the character "å…¥" was easily confused with the character "äºº". In order to distinguish between the two characters, the word "å…¥" is gradually written in the form of right-handed over left-handed, which is common today.

The oracle bone inscription is used as the original meaning, referring to entering, "He Ji" 7840: "Yimao enters the merchant." "He Ji" 39990: "Tonight the king enters the business." It also refers to Gongna, "He Ji" 190 reverses: "The bird enters thirty", Refers to the bird gunner for thirty (a tortoise shell). The other word is also used as a place name, "Collection" 16348: "Only (in) enter."

Bronze inscriptions are also used in the original meaning, referring to entering, house: "The king used the Qing (é£¨) to enter and leave for thousands of years." It means that Wannian used this to eat banquets and run for the king. It also specifically refers to entering the royal court, Mao Gongding: "ğ©¹zhi, åº¶ enters into affairs (officials), in the outer å°ƒ (applied) to order å°ƒ (applied) politics." "In and out" refers to entering the royal court, the whole sentence refers to the past, the official in Wang Ting, issued administrative orders outside. The word is also used as " satisfaction, " which means dedication. Song Ding: "Song and worship the chief, the order book is worn out, and it enters the chapter of Violence." "Into the chapter of Violence", Guo Moruo reads "Return to Na Jinzhang", referring to the emperor of the Zhou Dynasty after being ordered by the king. There is Si Gong Na Meiyu in return.

The bamboo slips of the Warring States period were mostly pronounced as " in " with " inner ", "Shangbo Bamboo Book I." "Xing Qing Lun" Jane 10: "ğ¦¡Š (body) is not (its) appropriate (righteous) but abstains from it, inside (reason) is not (its) emotion and goes out of (in) it." The whole sentence refers to the appropriate behavior of experiencing his And use it with restraint, adjust his emotions and express it. See " inside ".
humanum_short_description_en: " into " basically a indicator, shaped like a pointed thing to point out the direction of "inbound" in.

Heisig: This character is meant to be a picture of someone walking leftwards, putting one leg forward in order to enter someplace. Since the "in" side of a character is the left, it should be easy to remember the writing of this character.
* As a primitive, the meaning of the key word is expanded to include: to go in, to put in, to come in, and the like. It generally appears atop its relative primitive, where, unlike the element for umbrella, the two strokes do not touch each other, making it virtually the same as the kanji for eight. When it appears in any other position, however, it retains its original form.

All those who enter are from the entry." " In" and " å…­" are the same characters, that is, the two characters have different meanings but the same writing , See " Six". The glyphs of the ancient characters for " entering" are generally symmetrical, which is different from the character " äºº", which has different lengths on the left and right. The characters of the Warring States Period may be decorated with dots on the vertical painting of the character " å…¥", as shown in the 208-character bamboo slips of the tomb of Zenghou Yi. In the process of the Libian change, because the left and right strokes of the character " äºº" became symmetrical, the character " å…¥" was easily confused with the character " äºº". In order to distinguish between the two characters, the word " å…¥" is gradually written in the form of right-handed over left-handed, which is common today. The oracle bone inscription is used as the original meaning, referring to entering, "He Ji" 7840: "Yimao enters the merchant." "He Ji" 39990: "Tonight the king enters the business." It also refers to Gongna, "He Ji" 190 reverses: "The bird enters thirty", Refers to the bird gunner for thirty (a tortoise shell). The other word is also used as a place name, "Collection" 16348: "Only (in) enter." Bronze inscriptions are also used in the original meaning, referring to entering, house: "The king used the Qing (é£¨) to enter and leave for thousands of years." It means that Wannian used this to eat banquets and run for the king. It also specifically refers to entering the royal court, Mao Gongding: "ğ©¹zhi, åº¶ enters into affairs (officials), in the outer å°ƒ (applied) to order å°ƒ (applied) politics." "In and out" refers to entering the royal court, the whole sentence refers to the past, the official in Wang Ting, issued administrative orders outside. The word is also used as " satisfaction," which means dedication. Song Ding: "Song and worship the chief, the order book is worn out, and it enters the chapter of Violence." "Into the chapter of Violence", Guo Moruo reads "Return to Na Jinzhang", referring to the emperor of the Zhou Dynasty after being ordered by the king. There is Si Gong Na Meiyu in return. The bamboo slips of the Warring States period were mostly pronounced as " in" with " inner", "Shangbo Bamboo Book I." "Xing Qing Lun" Jane 10: "ğ¦¡Š (body) is not (its) appropriate (righteous) but abstains from it, inside (reason) is not (its) emotion and goes out of (in) it." The whole sentence refers to the appropriate behavior of experiencing his And use it with restraint, adjust his emotions and express it. See " inside".
